videoInfo.description: This video explores entropy, a fundamental yet often misunderstood concept in physics, governing everything from molecular interactions to the universe's evolution. It uses the Earth's energy exchange with the sun as a starting point to reveal common misconceptions about energy use. Through the historical discoveries of Sadi Carnot, Lord Kelvin, Rudolf Clausius, and Ludwig Boltzmann, the video explains entropy as the tendency of energy to spread out, revealing why processes are irreversible and defining the "arrow of time" through statistical probability.

content.content: This is a video about one of the most important, yet least understood concepts in all of physics.
It governs everything from molecular collisions to humongous storms.
It may, in fact, determine the direction of time and even be the reason that life exists.
To see the confusion around this topic, you need to ask only one simple question. What does the Earth get from the sun?
For most of the earth's history, it should be exactly the same amount of energy in from the sun as earth radiates into space.
Then what are we really getting from the sun?

sections.title: Sadi Carnot and the Quest for Engine Efficiency

content.content: To answer that, we have to go back to a discovery made two centuries ago.
The son of one of Napoleon's generals was Sadi Carnot, a 17-year-old student.
His father was not only a general, but also a physicist.
When his son comes to visit, they talk at length about the big breakthrough of the time, steam engines.
And it was clear that the future industrial and military might of nations depended on having the best steam engines.
So, Sadi Carnot took it upon himself to figure out why.

sections.title: Carnot's Ideal Heat Engine: Mechanism and Limitations

content.content: So he spends the next three years studying heat engines, and one of his key insights involves how an ideal heat engine would work, one with no friction and no losses to the environment.
The engine consists of a chamber filled with air, where heat can only flow in or out through the bottom.
Through this process, heat from the hot bar is converted into the energy of the flywheel.
And what's interesting to note about Carnot's ideal engine is that it is completely reversible.
So by running an ideal engine, nothing really changes. You can always undo what you did.
Since it's fully reversible, you might expect the efficiency to be 100%, but that is not the case.

sections.title: Kelvin's Absolute Temperature Scale and Efficiency Formula

content.content: Lord Kelvin learns of Carnot's ideal heat engine and realizes it could form the basis for an absolute temperature scale.
This is the idea of absolute zero, and it would make for a 100% efficient engine.

Using this absolute temperature scale, the Kelvin scale, we can replace the amount of heat in and out with the temperature of the hot and cold side respectively, because they are directly proportional.
What we have learned is that the efficiency of an ideal heat engine doesn't depend on the materials or the design of the engine, but fundamentally on the temperatures of the hot and cold sides.
To reach 100% efficiency, you'd need infinite temperature on the hot side or absolute zero on the cold side, both of which are impossible in practice.
So even with no friction or losses to the environment, it's impossible to make a heat engine 100% efficient.
And that's because to return the piston to its original position, you need to dump heat into the cold bar.

sections.title: Real-World Engines and the Irreversibility of Energy

content.content: Now, in Carnot's time, high pressure steam engines could only reach temperatures up to 160 degrees Celsius.
So their theoretical maximum efficiency was 32%, but their real efficiency was more like 3%.
That's because real engines experience friction, dissipate heat to the environment, and they don't transfer heat at constant temperatures.
When energy spreads out like this, it is impossible to get it back.
So this process is irreversible.
The total amount of energy didn't change, but it became less usable.
Energy is most usable when it is concentrated and less usable when it's spread out.

sections.title: Clausius and the Laws of Thermodynamics: Defining Entropy

content.content: Decades later, German physicist, Rudolf Clausius, studies Carnot's engine, and he comes up with a way to measure how spread out the energy is.
He calls this quantity, entropy.
When all the energy is concentrated in the hot bar, that is low entropy, but as the energy spreads to the surroundings, entropy increases.
In 1865, Clausius summarizes the first two laws of thermodynamics like this.
First, the energy of the universe is constant. And second, the entropy of the universe tends to a maximum.
In other words, energy spreads out over time.
But I think the best way to think about entropy is as the tendency of energy to spread out.

sections.title: Boltzmann: Entropy as Probability and the Arrow of Time

content.content: So why does energy spread out over time?
I mean, most of the laws of physics work exactly the same way forwards or backwards in time.
This is where Ludwig Boltzmann made an important insight. Heat flowing from cold to hot is not impossible, it's just improbable.
That is the energy is more than six times as likely to be evenly spread between the bars.
So, why don't we observe this happening around us?
In everyday solids, there are around 100 trillion, trillion atoms and even more energy packets.
So heat flowing from cold to hot is just so unlikely that it never happens.
